data.title: Tennis champion Todd Woodbridge serves up racquets at Mount Cotton State School
data.meta_description: Grand Slam champion Todd Woodbridge has inspired Mt Cotton prep students to give tennis a go.
data.text:
HOT SHOTS: Prep students at Mount Cotton State School received tennis racquets from Grand Slam champion Todd Woodbridge as part of the ANZ Tennis Hot Shots Racquet Roadshow. Photo: Cheryl Goodenough

TWENTY-TWO-TIME Grand Slam champion Todd Woodbridge has visited students at Mount Cotton State School as part of countrywide efforts to inspire children to take up tennis.

Create a free account to read this article

Mr Woodbridge visited the school on Tuesday to hand over 90 tennis racquets as part of the ANZ Tennis Hot Shots Roadshow.

About 80,000 racquets will be delivered to schools across Australia over two years through the roadshow.

VISIT: Todd Woodbridge with Mount Cotton State School prep students Honor Coppen, Kobi Asplin and Grace Jagusic. Photo: Cheryl Goodenough

Mr Woodbridge said the project was aimed at getting children started in tennis.

“Tennis in Australia has always had a rich history and for too long we’ve been riding on that,” he said.

“Now it is again one of the most prominent sports in schools.”

TENNIS STAR: Todd Woodridge inspires students at Mount Cotton State School to have a go at tennis. Photo: Cheryl Goodenough

Mr Woodbridge said tennis was being taught during physical education classes at about 2500 schools which meant children, who might otherwise never have played tennis, were being exposed to the sport.

“The racquet initiative is a fantastic way to introduce and encourage more kids to play tennis and have fun, as well as help identify the future champions of our sport.”

CATCH: Todd Woodbridge throws a ball to a student during his talk at Mount Cotton State School. Photo: Cheryl Goodenough

The tennis star told the prep students at Mount Cotton about his first Wimbledon win in 1993, being part of the team to win the Davis Cup and his personal best, winning an Olympic Gold medal in 1996.

He showed them some of his trophies and medals before distributing the modified tennis racquets and balls.
